Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: The Wealthy and Stratification Ideologies

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1409232
Anthony S. Chen
Fiona C. Chin
Northwestern University

Economic inequality in the U.S. has been rising for the past thirty years. Social science research on the topic is developing rapidly, but there remains a paucity of research on what wealthy Americans know and believe about economic inequality. The stratification literature has examined the knowledge and beliefs of ordinary Americans along these lines, but we need to understand more about what the affluent know and think about economic inequality, as well as where their beliefs come from. This study investigates these questions by employing a multi-method approach. Using data from a representative survey of the wealthiest 1% of Chicago-area residents and original in-depth interviews with economically successful Americans from across the country, this study describes and explains the stratification ideologies of wealthy Americans. Specifically, the study aims to determine what the wealthy believe about the stratification order and their own place in it; where those beliefs come from (i.e., why they believe what they believe); what their preferences are for public and private interventions to ameliorate inequality; and what their ideas imply for whether and how the trend toward greater inequality may be addressed.

Broader Impacts

Economic inequality is widely regarded as one of the most important public policy issues of our time. The social science community has only begun to illuminate the complex trends, causes, and consequences of economic inequality. This study will contribute to this ongoing endeavor by documenting and explaining the beliefs about inequality held by wealthy Americans, a highly influential--but surprisingly understudied--segment of the population. This study is an interdisciplinary project at the intersection of Sociology and Political Science. Findings from this study will be disseminated to both academic and non-academic audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Economic inequality is widely regarded as one of the most important public policy issues of our time. Trends in wealth and income inequality show the increasing polarization between rich Americans and the rest of the population. The social science community has only begun to illuminate the complex causes and consequences of economic inequality. This study contributes to this ongoing endeavor by documenting and explaining the beliefs about inequality held by wealthy Americans, a highly influential—but surprisingly understudied—segment of the population. What the wealthy know and believe about the magnitude, sources, consequences, and desirability of growing inequality has clear and serious implications for whether and how the trend toward greater inequality can be addressed. If the rich do not believe that inequality is a problem for the country, then it is unlikely that politicians will act to reduce these growing disparities.

This is the first research project to describe and explain the stratification ideologies of Americans at the top of the wealth distribution. Using new data from 101 original, in-depth interviews with wealthy Americans from across the country, as well as representative survey data on wealthy Chicago-area residents, this project aims to develop an understanding of what the wealthy believe about the stratification order and their own place in it; where those beliefs come from (i.e. why they believe what they believe); what their preferences are for interventions to ameliorate inequality; and what that implies about the chances for reversing the trend of increasing inequality.

These new data show that the wealthy are ambivalent about economic inequality. Despite their answers to questions with closed-ended choices, indicating that they prefer less inequality than currently exists, in broader interview questions that allowed for nuanced, open-ended responses, the wealthy articulated their beliefs that inequality was due to individuals’ actions, effort, and character. The wealthy did not believe that any systematic barriers stymied middle-class Americans’ upward mobility. Consequently, they did not favor government intervention to ameliorate the trend of rising inequality. The wealthy view the free market as sacrosanct. The majority of interview subjects expressed a desire for the government to curtail spending on programs like welfare and food stamps because they create “negative incentives” for Americans to succeed on their own. Given the ambivalence that wealthy Americans feel towards inequality and whether anything needs to be done to redress the trend, and given the disproportionate political influence of the affluent, inequality may be unlikely to decline in the near future.
